cities.name: Cork

Art & Culture.name: Crawford Art Gallery
Art & Culture.description: A free public gallery filled with classical and contemporary Irish art ‚Äî a peaceful place to explore creativity in the city center.

Art & Culture.name: Cork City Gaol
Art & Culture.description: A fascinating 19th-century prison museum where history comes alive through exhibitions and stories of Ireland‚Äôs past.

Art & Culture.name: Nano Nagle Place
Art & Culture.description: A museum, heritage center, and garden honoring one of Cork‚Äôs most inspiring educators and pioneers for social change.

Photo Spots.name: St. Patrick‚Äôs Street
Photo Spots.description: Cork‚Äôs vibrant main street lined with colorful buildings and shops ‚Äî especially photogenic during festivals or after rain when the lights reflect on the pavement.

Photo Spots.name: Shandon Bells & Tower (St. Anne‚Äôs Church)
Photo Spots.description: Climb the tower, ring the historic bells, and enjoy one of the best panoramic views of Cork city.

Food & Nightlife.name: Market Lane Restaurant
Food & Nightlife.description: A beloved local restaurant serving fresh, seasonal Irish dishes with a modern twist in a cozy atmosphere.

Food & Nightlife.description: An authentic Irish pub famous for live traditional music sessions and great energy every night.

Nature & Relaxation.name: Blarney Castle & Gardens
Nature & Relaxation.description: A short drive from Cork ‚Äî home to the famous Blarney Stone and beautiful green gardens.

cities.local_food_tip: Try a hearty bowl of seafood chowder or Irish stew at the English Market. For dessert, sample freshly baked scones with jam and cream or a slice of traditional apple tart.

full_day.morning: ‚òÄÔ∏è Start at the English Market for breakfast, then visit Crawford Art Gallery nearby.
full_day.afternoon: üè∞ Explore Cork City Gaol or walk through Fitzgerald Park along the River Lee.
full_day.evening: üåÜ Climb Shandon Tower for sunset views, then have dinner at Market Lane.
full_day.night: üåô End your day with live Irish music at Sin √â Pub or take a peaceful walk along the River Lee.

spring.highlight: The city blooms with color ‚Äî parks and riversides are perfect for walks.

ideas.name: Visit Fitzgerald Park
ideas.description: Enjoy spring flowers and sculptures while walking by the River Lee.

ideas.name: Day trip to Blarney Castle
ideas.description: See blooming gardens and kiss the famous Blarney Stone for good luck!

summer.highlight: Festivals, music, and long days make Cork lively and full of outdoor fun.

ideas.name: Cork Midsummer Festival
ideas.description: A vibrant celebration of art, theatre, and music across the city.

ideas.name: Walk along the Lee Fields
ideas.description: Enjoy the sunshine and calm riverside paths popular with locals.

autumn.highlight: Golden leaves and harvest flavors make Cork cozy and charming.

ideas.name: Cork Jazz Festival
ideas.description: One of Europe‚Äôs top jazz festivals, filling the city with music and energy.

ideas.name: Coffee and books at a local caf√©
ideas.description: Relax with coffee, cake, and good reads as the weather cools down.

winter.highlight: Twinkling Christmas lights, cozy pubs, and warm comfort food.

ideas.name: Cork Christmas Market
ideas.description: Enjoy festive lights, hot chocolate, and ice skating on Grand Parade.

ideas.name: Evening at Sin √â
ideas.description: Warm up by the fire with live folk music and friendly locals.

public_transport_tips.tip: Cork‚Äôs city buses are run by Bus √âireann ‚Äî routes cover all main areas, and tickets can be bought via the TFI Go app.
The train station connects Cork to Dublin, Cobh, and other towns for easy day trips.
Walking is one of the best ways to explore ‚Äî most attractions are within 15‚Äì20 minutes of each other downtown.

city_events.description: Cork Midsummer Festival ‚Äî a mix of art, theatre, and music performances around the city.
Cork Jazz Festival ‚Äî one of Ireland‚Äôs biggest music events attracting performers from all over the world.
Cork Christmas Market ‚Äî a festive fair with lights, crafts, and holiday treats on Grand Parade.

places.name: English Market
places.description: Cork‚Äôs iconic food market, full of local produce and vibrant energy.

places.name: Crawford Art Gallery
places.description: A historic art gallery featuring both Irish masters and new contemporary works.

places.name: Fitzgerald Park
places.description: A green oasis along the River Lee, perfect for picnics and quiet walks.

places.name: Shandon Bells
places.description: A historic church tower where visitors can ring the bells and enjoy panoramic views.

hidden_gems.name: Elizabeth Fort
hidden_gems.description: A 17th-century fort offering free entry and excellent views over the city rooftops.

hidden_gems.name: Butter Museum
hidden_gems.description: A quirky museum exploring Ireland‚Äôs butter-making history ‚Äî surprisingly fun and educational!

hidden_gems.name: Franciscan Well Brewery
hidden_gems.description: A craft brewery and beer garden set in a former monastery ‚Äî known for its pizzas and friendly vibe.

cities.name: Dublin

Art & Culture.name: Trinity College & The Book of Kells
Art & Culture.description: Ireland‚Äôs oldest university, home to the famous illuminated Book of Kells and the breathtaking Long Room Library.

Art & Culture.description: A beautiful gallery displaying works by Irish and European artists, including Caravaggio and Jack B. Yeats ‚Äî entry is free!

Art & Culture.name: EPIC The Irish Emigration Museum
Art & Culture.description: An interactive museum that tells the story of Irish people who left home and changed the world ‚Äî modern, digital, and fun.

Photo Spots.name: Ha‚Äôpenny Bridge
Photo Spots.description: A charming white pedestrian bridge across the River Liffey ‚Äî one of Dublin‚Äôs most photographed spots.

Photo Spots.description: A peaceful Victorian park with colorful flowers, ponds, and perfect places for photos and picnics.

Photo Spots.description: Cobblestone streets, murals, and lively music make this district full of life and color ‚Äî especially at sunset.

Food & Nightlife.description: A stylish restaurant serving classic Irish comfort food with a modern twist, right by the River Liffey.

Food & Nightlife.name: Gallagher‚Äôs Boxty House
Food & Nightlife.description: Try traditional Irish potato pancakes (boxty) in this cozy Temple Bar restaurant with great hospitality.

Nature & Relaxation.description: A seaside hike just outside Dublin with dramatic cliffs, sea views, and the best fish & chips nearby.

Nature & Relaxation.name: National Botanic Gardens
Nature & Relaxation.description: Beautiful glasshouses, exotic plants, and quiet garden paths ‚Äî perfect for a calm nature escape.

cities.local_food_tip: Try Irish stew, soda bread, or seafood chowder for classic comfort. For dessert, enjoy a slice of Baileys cheesecake or warm apple crumble with cream.

full_day.morning: ‚òÄÔ∏è Start your day with a tour of Trinity College and its famous Book of Kells.
full_day.afternoon: üèõÔ∏è Visit EPIC Museum and walk along the River Liffey, then stop for lunch at The Woollen Mills.
full_day.evening: üåÜ Relax in St. Stephen‚Äôs Green or shop on Grafton Street.
full_day.night: üåô Enjoy dinner at Boxty House and live traditional music at The Cobblestone.

spring.highlight: Cherry blossoms bloom in Dublin parks, and caf√© terraces start filling with locals.

ideas.name: Walk through St. Stephen‚Äôs Green
ideas.description: Enjoy flowers and fountains in Dublin‚Äôs most beautiful park.

ideas.name: Explore Trinity College Campus
ideas.description: The historic buildings look stunning surrounded by spring blossoms.

summer.highlight: Long days, music festivals, and outdoor activities make summer lively and fun.

ideas.name: Longitude Festival
ideas.description: A major music festival featuring top international and Irish artists.

ideas.name: Picnic in Phoenix Park
ideas.description: Bring snacks, rent a bike, and enjoy a summer day surrounded by deer and greenery.

autumn.highlight: Golden leaves decorate the city, and cultural festivals fill Dublin‚Äôs calendar.

ideas.name: Dublin Theatre Festival
ideas.description: One of Europe‚Äôs oldest theatre festivals with performances across the city.

ideas.name: Walk along the River Liffey
ideas.description: Enjoy reflections of autumn colors in Dublin‚Äôs heart.

public_transport_tips.tip: Use the Leap Card for discounts on buses, trams (LUAS), and trains ‚Äî available at convenience stores and stations.
Dublin Bus covers all city areas, and the LUAS tram is great for quick travel between the center and suburbs.
Walking is the best way to explore downtown ‚Äî most attractions are within 20 minutes of each other.

city_events.description: St. Patrick‚Äôs Day Parade ‚Äî Dublin‚Äôs biggest event, with colorful floats, music, and celebrations across the city.
Longitude Festival ‚Äî a weekend of pop, indie, and electronic music in Marlay Park.
Dublin Theatre Festival ‚Äî celebrating drama, storytelling, and performance arts.

places.name: Trinity College & Book of Kells
places.description: Ireland‚Äôs oldest university, home to the ancient Book of Kells and one of the world‚Äôs most beautiful libraries.

places.name: St. Stephen‚Äôs Green
places.description: A lovely city park perfect for a peaceful walk or picnic among flowers and fountains.

places.name: Temple Bar
places.description: The heart of Dublin‚Äôs nightlife, filled with music, art, and colorful cobbled streets.

places.name: Phoenix Park
places.description: One of Europe‚Äôs largest enclosed parks ‚Äî great for cycling, picnics, and spotting wild deer.

hidden_gems.description: A 300-year-old library near St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral ‚Äî full of ancient books and old-world charm.

hidden_gems.name: Little Museum of Dublin
hidden_gems.description: A small, fun museum that tells Dublin‚Äôs story through quirky exhibits and local humor.

cities.name: Galway

Art & Culture.description: One of Ireland‚Äôs most respected theater companies, presenting powerful Irish plays and new creative works.

Art & Culture.name: St. Nicholas‚Äô Collegiate Church
Art & Culture.description: The largest medieval parish church still in use in Ireland ‚Äî full of history and beautiful stained-glass windows.

Photo Spots.name: Salthill Promenade

spring.highlight: Flowers bloom in Eyre Square, and the city feels bright and fresh after winter.

ideas.name: Walk the Salthill Promenade
ideas.description: Enjoy the fresh sea air and blooming wildflowers along the bay.

ideas.name: Visit Galway Market

summer.highlight: Street performers, festivals, and sunshine make Galway lively and colorful.

ideas.name: Galway International Arts Festival
ideas.description: A world-famous celebration of art, theater, and music ‚Äî the city becomes one big stage.

ideas.name: Swim or relax at Salthill Beach

autumn.highlight: Harvest colors and seafood festivals make Galway cozy and full of flavor.

ideas.name: Galway Oyster Festival

ideas.name: Coffee at a riverside caf√©

public_transport_tips.tip: Galway‚Äôs main bus station and train station are beside Eyre Square ‚Äî everything downtown is walkable from there.
Local buses connect to Salthill, Barna, and Knocknacarra. Tickets can be paid via the TFI Go app or Leap Card.
For exploring Connemara or the Cliffs of Moher, book a one-day tour from Eyre Square or rent a car for scenic freedom.

city_events.description: Galway International Arts Festival ‚Äî two weeks of world-class art, theater, and live performances all over the city.
The Galway Races ‚Äî Ireland‚Äôs biggest horse racing event with fashion, music, and celebration.
Galway International Oyster Festival ‚Äî celebrating seafood, sea air, and great company.

places.name: Spanish Arch
places.description: A 16th-century arch by the river, now a favorite gathering spot for locals.

places.name: The Long Walk
places.description: Colorful houses by the harbor that have become Galway‚Äôs most iconic photo location.

places.name: Galway City Museum

places.name: Salthill Promenade

hidden_gems.name: R√≥is√≠n Dubh

cities.name: Killarney

Art & Culture.description: A stunning neo-Gothic cathedral built from local stone, known for its peaceful atmosphere and impressive architecture.

Photo Spots.name: Torc Waterfall
Photo Spots.description: A beautiful cascading waterfall surrounded by mossy forest ‚Äî especially magical after rain.

Photo Spots.name: Gap of Dunloe

Food & Nightlife.description: A cozy restaurant serving Irish classics like boxty and seafood chowder, paired with friendly service and local charm.

Nature & Relaxation.name: Killarney National Park

Nature & Relaxation.name: Lough Leane Boat Tour

Nature & Relaxation.name: Torc Mountain Hike
Nature & Relaxation.description: A moderately challenging hike offering breathtaking views over the lakes and surrounding countryside.

cities.local_food_tip: Try Irish boxty pancakes or lamb stew at Bric√≠n, and don‚Äôt miss a scoop of Murphy‚Äôs Ice Cream made from local milk and sea salt. Killarney‚Äôs caf√©s also serve great scones and tea for an afternoon treat!

full_day.morning: ‚òÄÔ∏è Start your day with a walk through Killarney National Park and visit Ross Castle on the lakeshore.
full_day.afternoon: üèûÔ∏è Hike to Torc Waterfall or enjoy a boat trip on Lough Leane, then have lunch at Bric√≠n Restaurant.
full_day.evening: üåÖ Drive to Ladies View for stunning sunset views over the lakes.
full_day.night: üåô Enjoy dinner and live music at The Laurels Pub ‚Äî a perfect end to your Killarney adventure.

spring.highlight: Wildflowers bloom across the national park, and the weather is cool and refreshing for hikes.

ideas.name: Visit Muckross Gardens
ideas.description: See blooming flowers and explore peaceful paths by the lakes.

ideas.name: Cycle through Killarney National Park
ideas.description: Rent a bike and ride through forests, waterfalls, and open meadows.

summer.highlight: Long sunny days and lively festivals make it the best season for outdoor adventures.

ideas.name: Boating on the Lakes
ideas.description: Take a scenic boat or kayak trip across the shimmering lakes.

ideas.name: Killarney Summerfest
ideas.description: A family-friendly festival full of music, food, and fun in the sunshine.

autumn.highlight: Golden leaves blanket the park, and cozy caf√©s welcome hikers and photographers.

ideas.name: Warm up at Bric√≠n Restaurant

public_transport_tips.tip: Killarney train station connects easily with Dublin and Cork ‚Äî it‚Äôs just a 5-minute walk from the town center.
Local shuttle buses and taxis can take you to nearby sights like Muckross House or the Gap of Dunloe.
Bikes are available for rent in town ‚Äî a fun and eco-friendly way to explore Killarney National Park.

city_events.description: Killarney Summerfest ‚Äî a celebration of Irish music, family fun, and outdoor entertainment.
Killarney Races ‚Äî horse racing with a lively atmosphere and stunning mountain views.
Christmas in Killarney Festival ‚Äî lights, parades, and Christmas cheer throughout the town.

places.name: Killarney National Park
places.description: Ireland‚Äôs oldest national park ‚Äî full of lakes, red deer, and ancient woodlands.

places.name: Muckross House

places.name: Torc Waterfall
places.description: A peaceful forest waterfall that‚Äôs one of Killarney‚Äôs most loved natural sites.

places.name: Ross Castle

hidden_gems.name: Kate Kearney‚Äôs Cottage

cities.name: Limerick

cities.local_food_tip: Try Irish stew, Limerick ham, or fish and chips at a local pub. Visit the Milk Market for fresh crepes, cheeses, and sweet treats. For dessert, have apple crumble with ice cream or a slice of Guinness cake!

full_day.morning: ‚òÄÔ∏è Start your day with coffee and breakfast at The Milk Market, then visit King John‚Äôs Castle to explore Limerick‚Äôs medieval roots.

full_day.night: üåô Dine at Cornstore Restaurant and finish the evening with live music at one of the city‚Äôs cozy pubs.

spring.highlight: Flowers bloom in the parks, and the riverside is perfect for peaceful walks.

ideas.name: Visit People‚Äôs Park

public_transport_tips.tip: Limerick‚Äôs Colbert Station serves both trains and buses ‚Äî perfect for day trips to Cork, Galway, or Dublin.
Bus √âireann runs regular routes across the city and to Shannon Airport ‚Äî the journey takes about 30 minutes.
Downtown is walkable, and cycling paths along the river make it easy to explore eco-friendly.

city_events.description: Riverfest Limerick ‚Äî a weekend of food, fireworks, live music, and river activities marking the start of summer.
Limerick Jazz Festival ‚Äî international artists bring smooth tunes and late-night concerts to venues around the city.
Limerick Christmas Market ‚Äî festive stalls, skating, and seasonal treats fill the city with sparkle and cheer.

places.name: King John‚Äôs Castle

places.name: Hunt Museum
